bioghist.p: Paul Burgess (1886-1958) and Dora McLaughlin Burgess (1887-1962) were appointed as missionaries to Guatemala by the PCUSA in 1912 and served there until their retirement in 1956. In 1932, Paul and Dora Burgess resigned their positions and amidst considerable controversy, decided to commence work with the Quiche Indians, a large but generally neglected segment of the Guatemalan population. They reduced the Quiche language to a modern written form, learned it and began producing Christian literature in it. In 1940, against the advice of the Presbyterian Mission, they founded one of the pioneer ecumenical projects in Latin America, the Quiche Bible Institute. This institution was established to provide spiritual training for the more than 300,000 Quiche Indians living in Guatemala. Paul Burgess also founded in 1915 El Noticiero Evangelico, a monthly magazine featuring local and world church news, and edited from 1922-23 El Mensajero Evangelico. The Burgesses also translated a number of materials into the Spanish and Quiche languages, including the New Testament, hymnals and miscellaneous Sunday School literature.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of correspondence of Paul and Dora Burgess, dating from 1912 to 1950. The letters, outgoing and some incoming, relate to the Burgesses' missionary work in Guatemala. Correspondents include supporters, fellow missionaries, Guatemala Mission staff, staff of the Board of Foreign Missions, and friends and family members. Some of the correspondence is in Spanish. The collection also includes reports, typed manuscripts of articles by Paul Burgess, and a newspaper clipping about the Burgesses from 1960.
